bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The Gilbert & Bennett School was constructed as a model school in Georgetown in 1915 using funds bequeathed in 1905 by Edwin Gilbert of the Gilbert & Bennett Mfg. Co., land donated by the company, and with the financial assistance and approval of the employees of the Gilbert & Bennett Mfg. Co., including the Miller family. Multiple generations of Georgetown families sent their children to the Gilbert & Bennett School until it closed in 1971. Subsequently the Landmark Academy and then the Rose Garden School sub-leased the building from the Georgetown Community Association. The Gilbert & Bennett School is now the home of the G&B Cultural Center. The school's auditorium, classrooms, and grounds have hosted, and continue to host, a variety of Georgetown community events and programs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the Gilbert & Bennett School Collection includes textbooks, class photographs and snapshots, extracurricular and classroom equipment, diplomas and graduation programs, newspaper clippings, and a large amount of materials, including scrapbooks, correspondence, and photographs, relating to educator and Gilbert & Bennett School principal Ina E. Driscoll.
